awd_abstract_narration:
This is a project in Lie theory and geometry. Named after the mathematician Sophus Lie, Lie theory may be described as the study of symmetries of spaces of solutions of systems of differential equations. Especially important are systems of equations that model classical and quantum mechanics. Geometric properties of solution spaces encode properties of the physical systems being modeled by the differential equations. This project will develop the connections between the geometric properties and symmetries of these solution spaces, using mainly algebraic techniques.
 
The research will focus on four specific projects. The first project will find a twisted analog of conformal blocks and the Verlinde formula, the second project is to determine an irredundant set of Inequalities for the saturated tensor cone of a Kac-Moody Lie algebra, the third project will generalize the classical Jacobson-Morozov Theorem to symmetrizable Kac-Moody Lie Algebras, and the fourth project is to develop a general topological analog of Fulton's Conjecture for group restrictions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI (Shrawan Kumar) has continued his work in the general area of Lie Theory and Geometry. The four projects from his last grant proposal underline the theme of unity in Mathematics as they derive ideas from several areas of mathematics including Topology, Combinatorics, Algebraic Geometry and Representation Theory and also from other subjects such as Mathematical Physics. These projects represent some of the very difficult and important problems of current interest which have significant consequences in Mathematics and Mathematical Physics.  In addition, it is expected that in the near future the solutions will spawn a lot of activity in the subject. The PI has completed a book on  Conformal Blocks, Generalized Theta Functions and the Verlinde formula, which is being published soon by the Cambridge University Press. This is the very first book on the subject. It is expected that it will serve as a basic source in the subject for graduate students and professional mathematicians and mathematical physicists alike thus substantially promoting teaching and learning. The two books written earlier by the PI (one coauthored with M. Brion from France) have become standard texts on the subject. The PI has successfully supervised eleven PhD students and one Master's student. He is currently supervising two PhD students. He has co-organized four prestigious conferences in USA since 2016, including one at Nashville (April 2018) bringing Mathematicians and Theoretical Computer Scientists together and the one Sectional Meeting of the American Mathematical Society held at Auburn University during March, 2019. The PI has given several series of lectures on his works in the recent past at various places including: Lyon (June 2017), Mumbai (January 2018) and Bad Honnef (March 2018). These lectures have benefited a good number of students, postdocs and faculty members to bring them up to the new frontier of the subject. He has also given invited talks in 17 international conferences (since 2015) in various countries including Italy, Sweden, Germany, Australia, Taiwan, India, France, Israel, South Korea  and USA.
